questions.question: What is a key distinction between a research hypothesis and a statistical hypothesis?
options: Research hypotheses describe phenomena in the real world while statistical hypotheses speak about the data and are ambivalent about the real world
Research hypotheses are always testable through data collection while statistical hypotheses are theoretical constructs
Research hypotheses are fictional statements designed to be rejected while statistical hypotheses describe real-world phenomena
Research hypotheses focus on data analysis while statistical hypotheses deal with theoretical concepts
Research hypotheses are always directly testable with data while statistical hypotheses are abstract and theoretical

questions.question: What is a purpose of the null hypothesis in the context of significance hypothesis testing?
options: To directly support the research hypothesis
To describe a state of the world that is known to be true
To provide a baseline expectation that is assumed to be true unless there is sufficient evidence to reject it
To provide a definitive explanation for observed phenomena
To guide the collection of data

questions.question: In the thought experiment involving high and low social media users, what does the null hypothesis predict about the average well-being scores of the two groups?
options: The average well-being scores of high social media users will be significantly higher than those of low social media users.
The average well-being scores of low social media users will be significantly higher than those of high social media users.
The average well-being scores of the two groups will be statistically equivalent.
The well-being scores will be perfectly correlated between the two groups.
The relationship between social media usage and well-being is unpredictable

questions.question: The lecture mentions that frequent statistics are not generally best suited for what purpose?
options: Deriving null hypotheses
Collecting data
Testing research hypotheses
Making claims about alternative hypotheses
Formulating statistical hypotheses

questions.question: A p-value greater than 0.05 indicates a less than 5% chance of observing the data if the null hypothesis is true
A one-sided test is generally more lenient than a two-sided test with respect to significance thresholds
Type 1 error is also known as a false negative
Increasing sample size always decreases the power of a statistical test
What does a two-sided test evaluate?
options: Whether an observation is simply unlikely relative to the mean
Whether an observation is substantially less than the expected mean
Whether an observation is substantially greater than the expected mean
Whether the sample size is adequate
Whether the data is normally distributed

questions.question: Which of the following describes Type II error?
options: Rejecting a true effect as a null effect
Describing an effect when it does not exist
Setting an incorrect p-value threshold
Using an inappropriate statistical test
Having a sample that is too large

questions.question: What is the relationship between sample size and statistical power, as described in the lecture?
options: Increasing sample size decreases statistical power
Decreasing sample size increases statistical power
Increasing sample size generally increases statistical power
Sample size and statistical power are unrelated
Sample size only affects type 1 error

questions.question: For Q1, provide the code for running the binomial test. Then state whether the observed proportion of heads were signficantly different from the null.
For Q2, provide the code for checking bias against immigrants from Tonga. Is there a significant bias?
For Q3, describe the code for checking preference towards immigrants from Vanuatu.  Is there a significant preference?
